docs.snippet: 4:25 p.m. | Updated Added comments from interview with NPD analyst by Brian X. Chen.  The revamped Chrome operating system, announced Tuesday by Google, plays high-definition video, has a rebuilt trackpad and is even designed to work on future tou...
docs.lead_paragraph: 4:25 p.m. | Updated Added comments from interview with NPD analyst by Brian X. Chen. The revamped Chrome operating system, announced Tuesday by Google, plays high-definition video, has a rebuilt trackpad and is even designed to work on future touch-screen models. None of which matters if Google cannot get computers that use it out into the world, something that is proving as big a challenge as engineering Chrome. One thing is certain, however: Google is not giving up. It is heading to retail outlets, showcasing the machines as cheap and easy to manage corporate devices, and rethinking how it sells products for education. Executives involved with Chrome say Google doesn't care if it takes years for the Chrome operating system to catch on. (Google also calls its Web browser Chrome.)

headline.main: Google's Struggle To Sell Chrome

docs.abstract: Bits blog notes Google will continue with marketing efforts for its revamped Chrome operating system, despite lackluster sales. (M)

byline.original: By QUENTIN HARDY and BRIAN X. CHEN

docs.snippet: Q.I am going to Europe and plan to take my mobile phone. I looked on the power adapter and the label said it ranges from 100 to 240 volts. Does that mean I don't need to pack an electrical converter for the trip?     A. Most consumer electronic de...
docs.lead_paragraph: Q.I am going to Europe and plan to take my mobile phone. I looked on the power adapter and the label said it ranges from 100 to 240 volts. Does that mean I don't need to pack an electrical converter for the trip? A. Most consumer electronic devices like mobile phones, media players, cameras, laptops and e-book readers and so on come with power adapters that can handle a range of voltage and frequencies without an extra converter. If the label on your adapter says something like ''Input: 100-240VAC,'' with a reference to ''50-60 Hz,'' it should be fine operating in countries with electrical voltage running between 100 volts and 240 volts, and frequencies of 50 to 60 Hertz.

headline.main: Cellphone Power Abroad

docs.snippet: Barack Obama won 52.9 percent of the popular vote in 2008 and 365 electoral votes, 95 more than he needed. Many naturally concluded that prejudice was not a major factor against a black presidential candidate in modern America. My research, a comp...
docs.lead_paragraph: Barack Obama won 52.9 percent of the popular vote in 2008 and 365 electoral votes, 95 more than he needed. Many naturally concluded that prejudice was not a major factor against a black presidential candidate in modern America. My research, a comparison of Americans' Google searches and their voting patterns, found otherwise. If my results are correct, racial animus cost Mr. Obama many more votes than we may have realized. Quantifying the effects of racial prejudice on voting is notoriously problematic. Few people admit bias in surveys. So I used a new tool, Google Insights, which tells researchers how often words are searched in different parts of the United States.

headline.main: How Racist Are We? Ask Google

docs.abstract: Campaign Stops column by Seth Stephens-Davidowitz, a doctoral candidate at Harvard, describes his research on whether prejudice was a factor in the 2008 presidential election; contends that, using Americans' Google searches and their voting patterns, his research suggests that racial animus cost Pres Obama many more votes than people realize; reflects on what this means for the 2012 election. Photo, Chart (M)

docs.snippet: If Microsoft couldn't find compelling enough reasons to release its Office applications for the iPad, Google just gave it one.     On Tuesday, Google acquired Quickoffice, a start-up that makes a set of applications for iPads and Android tablets t...
docs.lead_paragraph: If Microsoft couldn't find compelling enough reasons to release its Office applications for the iPad, Google just gave it one. On Tuesday, Google acquired Quickoffice, a start-up that makes a set of applications for iPads and Android tablets that let people open and edit Microsoft Word, Excel and PowerPoint files. Productivity apps are among the best sellers in the category of paid apps for the iPad. Quickoffice currently ranks seventh on that list in Apple's iPad App Store.

headline.main: Battle Nears For Office Apps

docs.abstract: Bits blog notes Google is acquiring Quickoffice, start-up that makes apps for iPads and Android tablets; points out acquisition puts pressure on rival Microsoft to release its Office apps for the iPad. (M)

docs.snippet: Some years ago, an engineer at Google told me why Google was not collecting information linked to people's names: ''We don't want the name. The name is noise.'' There was enough information in Google's large database of search queries, location an...
docs.lead_paragraph: Some years ago, an engineer at Google told me why Google was not collecting information linked to people's names: ''We don't want the name. The name is noise.'' There was enough information in Google's large database of search queries, location and online behavior, he said, that a lot could be told about somebody through indirect means. The point was that actually finding out people's names is not necessary for sending them targeted ads. But increasingly, everything about you is out there. Whether and how you guard your privacy in an online world we are building up every day has become urgent.

headline.main: Big Data Era And Privacy

docs.abstract: Bits blog notes Microsoft Research researcher Danah Boyd believes regulation is coming regarding online privacy. Photo (M)1

docs.abstract: Google releases documents related to a federal investigation of its Street View mapping project; documents include sworn declarations from what appear to be engineers saying they were not aware of unauthorized data collection gathered from wireless networks as specially equipped cars passed through neighborhoods.

docs.snippet: Google has released a trove of documents related to a federal investigation into its Street View mapping project. Among the documents were sworn declarations from several employees familiar with Street View denying knowledge that the cars were col...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google has released a trove of documents related to a federal investigation into its Street View mapping project. Among the documents were sworn declarations from several employees familiar with Street View denying knowledge that the cars were collecting information traveling over personal Wi-Fi networks, also known as “payload data.”

headline.main: Google Engineers and Payload Data

docs.snippet: Google wants love. But so do six other companies. They are after .love, actually, a new ''top-level domain'' that could catch on as .com, .org and .net did.     Love might not prevail, but chances are, at least one of the domains in 1,930 applicat...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google wants love. But so do six other companies. They are after .love, actually, a new ''top-level domain'' that could catch on as .com, .org and .net did. Love might not prevail, but chances are, at least one of the domains in 1,930 applications for new extensions will. The domains are the letters that follow the dot in Internet addresses, and the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, known as Icann, revealed the new requests on Wednesday.

headline.main: Imagining Dot Magic In a Name

docs.abstract: Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers receives 1,930 applications from companies for new top-level domain names; .app is the most requested extension, with 13 applicants; Icann is expected to approve hundreds of these extensions, the first of which should be in use by 2013. Photo (M)

headline.main: Apple and Google Go Head to Head Over Mobile Maps
headline.print_headline: Head to Head Over Mobile Maps

docs.abstract: Apple’s move into mobile maps is hardly a surprise, but the question is if it can build a service that does as good a job, or a better one, than Google has; if Apple slips up, consumers in the highly competitive smartphone market may have a good reason to turn to Android phones; if Apple succeeds, Google will be under pressure at a time when it already has to deal with competitors in map services.

docs.snippet: Ever had to ignore a call because you were in a meeting or other situation that made answering not an option? Smartphones running the Android 4.0 software (also known as the Ice Cream Sandwich update, in accordance with Google's dessert-themed nic...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ever had to ignore a call because you were in a meeting or other situation that made answering not an option? Smartphones running the Android 4.0 software (also known as the Ice Cream Sandwich update, in accordance with Google's dessert-themed nicknaming scheme) offer a convenient feature that lets you respond to the caller with a text message. When a phone rings (or vibrates) and the incoming-call screen appears, swipe your finger up to the message icon to open a menu of canned responses like ''I'll call you later.'' You can also tap out a custom message on the spot or compose your own response for the menu -- just press the Menu icon, choose Settings and, in the Call Settings area, tap Quick Responses. On the Edit Quick Responses screen, tap a response in the list to edit it.

headline.main: Tip Of The Week

docs.abstract: Personal Tech Tip of the Week notes that smartphones running the Android 4.0 software offer feature that lets user respond to a caller with a text message instead of answering. (M)0

headline.main: Google Cuts Prices for Map Use by Site Owners

docs.abstract: Google is bowing to criticism and defections and cutting the prices it charges for heavy use of its maps by Web sites. The price of a million downloads a day will fall to less than $500 from almost $4,000.

headline.main: Flipboard, Another Apple Darling, Expands to Android

docs.abstract: Yet another app that was exclusive to Apple's mobile devices is expanding to Google's Android platform and elsewhere. What's unusual about the company behind this app, Flipboard, is that it was co-founded by a former Apple employee who worked on the iPhone.

docs.snippet: Though the weather may not affect your road trip as dramatically as it would have in tornado-ravaged Hampton, Va., this month, it still can dramatically alter your drive.      For travelers who don't want to set out for their dream destination and...
docs.lead_paragraph: Though the weather may not affect your road trip as dramatically as it would have in tornado-ravaged Hampton, Va., this month, it still can dramatically alter your drive. For travelers who don't want to set out for their dream destination and find, say, trees being uprooted along their path, Weather.com has created Trip Planner, an online tool that forecasts the weather along your route. The relatively simple interface allows you to enter the location you're traveling from and your final stop and reveals weather icons over the route. While it does not provide point-by-point directions, it does provide a link to Google maps, populated with your travel information. The forecasts can be predicted up to five days in advance. After that, their accuracy diminishes to a point at which you wouldn't rely on them to decide your outerwear, let alone chart your course.

headline.main: An App That Can Predict Sunny or Stormy Drives

docs.abstract: In Transit blog; Trip Planner, online tool from Weather.com, allows travelers to find forecasts for weather along a planned route. Photo (M)

docs.snippet: This summer, New York subway riders might be able to actually get some work done on the train (instead of just playing Temple Run on their smartphones). Beginning Monday, free Wi-Fi will be available at a number of stations courtesy of Google....

headline.main: Google Brings Free Wi-Fi to Some New York Subway Stations

docs.abstract: This summer, New York subway riders might be able to actually get some work done on the train (instead of just playing Temple Run on their smartphones). Beginning Monday, free Wi-Fi will be available at a number of stations courtesy of Google.

docs.snippet: Workplace hooky, a hallowed tradition that put so many salesmen into movie matinees between customer calls, is so Web 1.0.     On Thursday, Google announced a product that enables a business to see where all its workers are at all times. Called Ma...
docs.lead_paragraph: Workplace hooky, a hallowed tradition that put so many salesmen into movie matinees between customer calls, is so Web 1.0. On Thursday, Google announced a product that enables a business to see where all its workers are at all times. Called Maps Coordinate, it combines a paid-for business version of Google's standard maps product with an application downloaded to a worker's smartphone, creating a real-time record of worker locations.

headline.main: From Google, A Mapping App Tracks Workers

docs.abstract: Bits blog notes Google introduces its Maps Coordinate smartphone app, which lets a business see where all its workers are at all times. (M)

docs.abstract: A neural network of computer processors, fed millions of YouTube videos, taught itself to recognize cats, a feat of significance for fields like machine vision and perception, speech recognition and language translation.

docs.lead_paragraph: A neural network of computer processors, fed millions of YouTube videos, taught itself to recognize cats, a feat of significance for fields like speech recognition.

headline.seo: In a Big Network of Computers, Evidence of Machine Learning
headline.main: How Many Computers to Identify a Cat? 16,000
headline.print_headline: How Many Computers to Identify a Cat? 16,000

docs.abstract: Google scientists created one of the largest neural networks for machine learning by connecting 16,000 computer processors, which they then turned loose on the Internet to independently learn; network, presented with 10 million digital images found in YouTube videos, taught itself to recognize cats, a feat of significance for fields like speech recognition.

docs.snippet: Facebook said on Monday that its chief operating officer, Sheryl K. Sandberg, had joined the social network's board, becoming the first woman to serve as a director for the company.     The elevation of Ms. Sandberg, who joined Facebook in 2008, i...
docs.lead_paragraph: Facebook said on Monday that its chief operating officer, Sheryl K. Sandberg, had joined the social network's board, becoming the first woman to serve as a director for the company. The elevation of Ms. Sandberg, who joined Facebook in 2008, is an acknowledgment of the crucial role she plays at the company. Lured away from Google, she became one of Facebook's most public figures, making regular appearances at events like the World Economic Forum and the annual Allen & Company media conference in Sun Valley, Idaho.

headline.main: Sandberg, Prominent Facebook Officer, Is Elevated to Its Board

docs.abstract: Facebook says its chief operating officer, Sheryl K Sandberg, has joined the board, becoming the first woman to serve as a director for the company. (M)

docs.abstract: Google unveiled its new Nexus Q media player, a gamble that people are interested in making their home entertainment more social. At $299, the Q is pricier than competitors like Apple TV and Internet TV systems like Boxee. It is intended to make it easy to share content.

headline.main: Will Google's Personal Assistant Be Creepy or Cool?

docs.abstract: Google Now raises questions about the line between when tech is helpful and when it makes users uneasy. The service will do things like remind an Android owner that they have a lunch date — but also who it is with, how to get there and when they should leave, based on traffic.

docs.snippet: This is the second in a series of Q&As from the CHI 2012 conference that took place May 5-10 in Austin. I spoke with Kia Hook, from KTH in Sweden, and Ed Chi, from Google Research, the conference's two technical program chairs. They talked general...

headline.main: CHI 2012 Conference Q&A With Kia Hook and Ed Chi

docs.abstract: This is the second in a series of Q&As from the CHI 2012 conference that took place May 5-10 in Austin. I spoke with Kia Hook, from KTH in Sweden, and Ed Chi, from Google Research, the conference's two technical program chairs. They talked generally about exciting developments in their field, human-computer interaction (HCI), as well as specifically about the relationship of HCI to media and journalism.
